[Mor lam](/wiki/Mor_lam) - [Ram wong](/wiki/Romvong) - Ram Thai - Rabam - [Kingkara](/wiki/Peacock_dance) Vietnam - [Nhã nhạc](/wiki/Nh%C3%A3_nh%E1%BA%A1c) - v - t - e ***Zapin*** ([Jawi](/wiki/Jawi_script): **زافين**) is one of the most popular dance and musical forms in traditional Malay performing arts. Dance movements are choreographed to melodies, which are performed using musical instruments such as the gambus (short-necked lute), accordion, and rebana. It is believed to have been introduced by [Persian](/wiki/Persian_People) and [Arab](/wiki/Arab_People) [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim) missionaries from the Middle East to the [Malay Archipelago](/wiki/Malay_Archipelago) around the fourteenth century, where back then only males were allowed to perform; nowadays, female dancers are included. It used to be performed exclusively for religious ceremonies but through the years it has become a form of traditional entertainment, hence the participation of female dancers is allowed. ## Instruments The dancers usually perform in pairs and are accompanied by musicians playing the [accordion](/wiki/Accordion), [violin](/wiki/Violin), [gambus](/wiki/Qanb%C5%ABs), [gendang](/wiki/Kendang), [marwas/marawis](/wiki/Mirwas), and [rebana](/wiki/Rebana). ## Distributions Presently, zapin remains an integral part of the regional Malay performing arts scene, particularly in [Brunei Darussalam](/wiki/Brunei_Darussalam), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and Singapore. In Malaysia, Zapin is mostly associated with the Malaysian southern state of Johor. In [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), *Zapin* is mostly associated and classified as part of [Malay](/wiki/Malay_People) cultures especially in terms of traditional dances and traditions in [Malay-populated areas](/wiki/Malay_Indonesians) in [Sumatra](/wiki/Sumatra), [Riau Islands](/wiki/Riau_Islands), [Bangka Belitung Islands](/wiki/Bangka_Belitung_Islands), and [Kalimantan](/wiki/Kalimantan). ## Types There are numerous types of Zapin, and each type varies by the movement and style of dance: -
